required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Laser Versus Ultrasonic Lithotripsy in Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy for Staghorn Stones
clinical_study.official_title: Laser Versus Ultrasonic Lithotripsy in Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy for Staghorn Stones

brief_summary.textblock: This study will be conducted to compare the results of Laser and ultrasonic lithotripsy in disintegration of staghorn stones during percutaneous nephrolithotomy.

detailed_description.textblock:
Patients with complete staghorn stones who are eligible to percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PNL) will be randomized between two groups.
Group 1: will undergo Laser lithotripsy during PNL Group 2: will undergo ultrasonic lithotripsy during PNL

primary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be followed for 3 months after the procedure
primary_outcome.description: Assessment of stone free rate after 3 months from treatment using NCCT

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of the safety of each technique
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From the start of the operation till 3 months after discharge from the hospital
secondary_outcome.description: Measurement of complication rates, classifications of the severity of complications
Measurement of the time from start of ureteral catheter fixation till the fixation of the nephrostomy tube

intervention.description: Patients will undergo laser lithotripsy durin PNL
Patients will undergo ultrasonic lithotripsy during PNL

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Complete staghorn stones (filling the renal pelvis and branching to 3 major calyces
2. Age: 18-70 years
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Congenital renal anomalies such as horse shoe kidney.
2. Contraindications to PNL such as bleeding tendency and uncontrolled hypertension.
3. Associated pathological features requiring open intervention such as UPJO
4. Partial staghorn stones (filling the renal pelvis and branching to 2 major calyces)
5. Giant staghorn stone (very large staghorn stone that branch and re-branch in hugely dilated calyceal system)
